   Content: â€œDragons are Tricksyâ€: The Uncanny Dragons of Childrenâ€™s Literature | Fafnir â€“ Nordic Journal of Science Fiction and Fantasy Research , Volume 1, Issue 2, pages 41â€“54. Emily Midkiff â€œDragons are Tricksyâ€: The Uncanny Dragons of Childrenâ€™s Literature Abstract : As early as the sixties, scholars of childrenâ€™s literature have noted a trend to soften and satirize the dragon for children. This disconnect with traditional dragons has been bemoaned as ruining the mythic and archetypal power of dragons. Yet there may be more potent dragons lurking in childrenâ€™s literature than readily apparent, due to one significant aspect of traditional Western dragon-lore: the eerie feeling or mood cast by a dragon. The original dragons of Germanic lore, from which many childrenâ€™s literature dragons descended, were not just large scary beasts, but they also created a distinctly unsettling atmosphere in their stories. Modern tamed and human-like childrenâ€™s literature dragons borrow certain uncanny qualities...
